subsection.title: 2. Solve a linear inequality
subsection.p: The rules for solving an inequality are the same as those for solving an equation, with one important difference:

assemblage.p: If we multiply or divide both sides by a negative number, we must reverse the direction of the inequality.

statement.p: Solve ~~-3x+1 \gt 7~~ and graph the solutions on a number line.

solution.p: \begin{aligned}[t] -3x+1-1 \amp \gt 7-1 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Subtract 1 from both sides.}}\\ -3x \amp \gt 6 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by -3, and reverse the direction of the inequality.}}\\ x \amp \gt -2 \amp \amp \end{aligned} The solutions are all the numbers less than -2. The graph of the solutions is shown below.

statement.p: Solve ~~-3 \lt 2x-5 \le 6~~ and graph the solutions on a number line.

solution.p: \begin{aligned}[t] -3 \amp \lt 2x-5 \le 6 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Add 5 on all three sides of the inequality.}}\\ 2 \amp \lt 2x \le 11 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide each side by 2.}}\\ 1 \amp \lt x \le \dfrac{11}{2} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Notice that we did not reverse the inequality.}} \end{aligned} The solutions are all the numbers greater than 1 but less than 5.5. solution.p: Show that substituting -5 for x makes the equation true. \begin{aligned}[t] x^2+2x-15 \amp = (\alert{-5})^2+2(\alert{-5})-15\\ \amp = 25-10-15=0 \end{aligned}

statement.p: Verify that x=-3 is not a solution of the equation ~~\sqrt{2x+10}-3x=8.

solution.p: Show that substituting -3 for x does not make the equation true. \begin{aligned}[t] \sqrt{2x+10}-3x \amp = \sqrt{2(\alert{-3})+10}-3(\alert{-3})\\ \amp = \sqrt{4}+9=2+9=11 \not= 8 \end{aligned}

subsection.title: 4. Solve an equation in two variables

statement.p: Is (-3,2) a solution of the equation ~~x^2+4y^2=25 ?

solution.p: Substitute x=\alert{-3} and y=\alert{2} into the equation. (\alert{-3})^2+4(\alert{2})^2=9+4(4)=9+16=25 The ordered pair (-3,2) satisfies the equation, so it is a solution.
